questions.text: Do you ensure that data you hold of your clients like name and bank account information are accurate and up to date?
options: Yes, we allow clients to contact us if their details have changed
Yes, we frequently contact our clients to ensure their details are up to date
No, we do not check if our clients details are up to date
questions.explanation: The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to ensure that client information is accurate and up to date, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm keep data longer than is necessary?
options: Yes, we keep hold of it in case we need it
No, we delete it when it is not needed anymore
questions.explanation: The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to dispose of user data if it is no longer needed or relevant, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm allow clients rights to access a copy of the personal data you hold on them?
options: Yes, we have a simple process for clients to obtain a copy of their personal data
No, we do not allow clients to obtain a copy of their personal data
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal right for your clients to have a copy of the personal data your firm holds on them
if they do wish to have one, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text:
If your accountancy firm processes sensitive data (such as ethnicity, health data or bank account information),
 how often are Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) carried out?
options: Every year
Every 3 years
Every 5 years
Every 7+ years
We do not carry out data protection impact assessments
We do not process sensitive data
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to carry out DPIA's at least every 3 years or less
if sensitive data is stored about data subjects, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Do you ensure that clients give detailed consent prior to data collection/processing
options: Yes, we ensure clients give detailed consent prior to data collection
We ensure clients give consent prior to data collection but consent is not detailed
No, we do not ask for consent prior to data collection
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to receive detailed consent by the data subject,
prior to collecting data on them, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm delete client data, such as name and bank account information, that is inaccurate and outdated?
options: Yes, but only after they notify us that it is outdated
No, we keep it for our records
questions.explanation: The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to dispose of client information if it no longer needed or relevant, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm use encryption methods to protect client data during collection and transmission?
options: Yes, we use encryption technologies when collecting and transmissing client data
No, we do not use encryption technologies when collecting or transmitting client data
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to have appropriate technical and organisational
measures in place to ensure data security, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm ensure that client data collected is specific, explicit and legitimate for what its needed for?
options: Yes
No
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to have legitimate and legal
purposes for collecting data from clients, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Under your company procedure, how quick does your accountancy firm notify the ICO if in the event of a data breach?
options: Within 36 Hours
Within 72 Hours
72+ Hours
We do not contact the ICO in the event of a data breach
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to notify the Information Commissioner's Office,
in the event of a data breach within 72 hours, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Under your company procedure, how often is client data backed up?
options: Once a day
Once a week
Once a month
Once a year
We do not backup our data
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to have appropriate technical and organisational measures in place
to ensure data security, which includes frequent backups of data, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm store client passwords/bank details using encryption?
options: Yes
No
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to have appropriate technical and organisational measures in place
to ensure data security, which includes encryption usage such as hashing, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm have an appointed Data Protection Officer (DPO)?
options: Yes
No
questions.explanation: The UK GDPR states that it recommended for your firm to have an appointed DPO, especially when your firm stores bank account information and addresses

questions.text:
Do your accountants that handle client data receive GDPR/Data protection training?
If so, how often do they receive said training?
options: Yes, once a year
Yes, once every 2 years
Yes, every 3+ years
No
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is recommended for your firm to ensure training is carried out on accountants regularly in regards to GDPR and data protection principles,
especially with access to bank account information and addresses

questions.text:
If your accountancy firm receives or tranfers data outside the UK or EEA,
do you ensure that the destination country has an adequate amount of data security?
options: Yes
No
We do not transfer data outside of the UK/EEA
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to ensure that data being sent or received from a country
outside the UK or EEA has an adequate amount of data security, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: When clients make a right to erasure request, how long does it take for your accountancy firm to delete client data?
options: Within a month
Longer than a month
We do not monitor right to erasure requests
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to respond to a right to erasure request
within a month of the request being made, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm ensure that third-party data processors comply with GDPR when processing client data?
options: Yes, have checks in place to ensure compliance
No, we do not check for compliance
We do not have third-party processors
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to ensure that any third-party data processors that
process or store client data comply with the GDPR, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text:
Before collecting client data, do you inform the client of all of their detailed rights under the UK GDPR?
such as the right to erasure, right to object, right to be informed, etc.
options: Yes, we inform clients of all of their rights before data collection
Yes, we inform clients of all of their rights prior to data collection, but not detailed
We inform clients of some of their rights prior to data collection
No, we do not inform clients of their rights prior to data collection
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm inform your data subjects of all of their
relevant data privacy rights under the UK GDPR, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: In the event of a data breach, does your accountancy firm have a written procedure for system recovery and mitigation?
options: Yes
No
questions.explanation:
The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to have appropriate technical and organisational measures in place
to ensure data security, which includes system recovery procedures, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm carry out regular audits to ensure compliance with the UK GDPR?
options: Yes
No
questions.explanation: The ICO recommends taking yearly audits to ensure compliance with the UK GDPR

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm have a procedure in place for notifying clients in an event of a data breach?
options: Yes, we notify clients immediately
Yes, we notify clients within a given timeframe
No
questions.explanation: The UK GDPR states that it is a legal obligation for your firm to notify clients in the event of a data breach as soon as possible, enforced by the Data Protection Act 2018

questions.text: Are employees in your accountancy firm trained not to access other staff's devices without permission?
options: Yes, we train employees not to access other staff hardware
No, we do not train employees to not access other staff hardware
I am self-employed and have no other staff
questions.explanation: Accessing somebody else's hardware without permission is illegal under the Unauthorised Access section of the Computer Misuse Act 1990

questions.text:
Does your accountancy firm have different levels of file access
to prevent employees from accessing company systems/client data without proper authorisation?
options: Yes, we have different levels of file access in place to ensure authorisation
No, we do not have different levels of file access
I am self-employed and have no other staff
questions.explanation:
Different levels of file access mitigates the risk of employees accessing data without being authorised to do so,
violating the Unauthorised Access section of the Computer Misuse Act 1990

questions.text: Does your accountancy firm have a procedure in place to immediately disable system access to employees who leave the company?
options: Yes, we have procedures in place to immediately disable system access to former staff
We have a procedure in place to disable system access to former staff, but not immediate
No, we do not have procedures in place to disable system access
I am self-employed and have no other staff
questions.explanation:
Disabling system access to former employees mitigates the risk of them accessing data without being authorised to do so,
violating the Unauthorised Access section of the Computer Misuse Act 1990

questions.text:
If devices in the office are likely to be used by multiple people,
do these devices have unique login credentials for each user?
options: Yes, shared devices have unique credentials for each user
No, shared devices do not have unique login credentials for each user
Our accountants work from home/use their own devices for work
I am self-employed and have no other staff
questions.explanation:
Unique login credentials for each employee mitigates the risk of employees accessing data without being authorised to do so,
violating the Unauthorised Access section of the Computer Misuse Act 1990

questions.text:
Is there a policy in place to prohibit employees from taking work-related
information outside of the firm without authorisation?
options: Yes, we have a policy to prohibit staff from taking work-related information
No, we do not have such policy in place
I am self-employed and have no other staff
questions.explanation: Taking work-related information without authorisation violates the Unauthorised Access section of the Computer Misuse Act 1990

questions.text: Does your accountants that handle personal data, only alter client data if given permission, or asked to by the client?
options: Yes, we only alter client data once asked by the client
No, we alter data without prior permission
questions.explanation: Modifying or deleting client data without permission violates the Unauthorised Modification section of the Computer Misuse Act 1990

questions.text:
Are background checks carried out on accountants that handle client data
to verify integrity, qualifications and criminal history?
options: Yes, we carry out background checks on our accountants
No, we do not carry out background checks on our accountants
I am self employed and have no other staff
questions.explanation: Employees who are not qualified to handle client data but do so will be violation of the Fraud by False Representation section of the Fraud Act 2006

questions.text:
Do employees use only company-approved software for sending or receiving sensitive client data
to prevent falsification risks, such as Sage?
options: Yes, we ensure that employees use only company-approved software
No, we do ensure that employees use only company-approved software
I am self employed and have no other staff
questions.explanation:
Employees who do not use company-approved software but is in contact of financial details may be at risk of invalidating the integrity of said data,
which may violate the Fraud by False Representation section of the Fraud Act 2006

questions.text:
Are accounts with access to sensitive bank details monitored for unusual activities;
such as access during closed hours, or data modification?
options: Yes, accounts with access to bank details are monitored for unusual activity
No, accounts with access to bank details are not monitored for unusual activity
questions.explanation:
Monitoring accounts with access to sensitive bank details will help mitigate the risk of employees accessing or using bank account information maliciously,
which violates the Fraud by Abuse of Position section of the Fraud Act 2006

questions.text:
Does your firm have policies that client instructions, such as large or unusual online transactions;
are verified for authentication prior to being carried out?
options: Yes, we ensure that client instructions are verified for authentication
No, we do not ensure that client instructions are verified for authentication
questions.explanation:
Ensuring that client instructions are verified for authentication helps mitigate the risk of employees using client bank account information maliciously,
which violates the Fraud by Abuse of Position section of the Fraud Act 2006
